story_headline: Rep. Ted Budd delivers victory speech after GOP N.C. senate primary win
story_copy: The power of former President Donald Trump‚Äôs endorsement is on full display as Congressman Ted Budd (R-N.C.) won North Carolina‚Äôs Republican senate primary.On Tuesday the Associated Press declared Budd as the winner with more than 56-percent of the vote and just over 25-percent having been counted. During his victory speech he thanked supporters and pledged to advance an America first agenda.‚ÄúI pledge to my fellow North Carolinians,‚Äù said the congressman.¬† ‚ÄúI will never waiver when it comes to fighting for the forgotten men and women in this state and in this country.‚ÄùTedd Budd speaking here at tonight‚Äôs election watch party after winning Republican nomination for US Senate.  @WFMY pic.twitter.com/9DPzDpdbVN‚Äî Brian Hall (@bhallwfmy) May 18, 2022He vowed to work on issues more important to his constituents, which he said include record high crime and inflation crisis. The Republican stressed that it‚Äôs unacceptable that working families in North Carolina will have to pay $5,200 extra this year due to inflation.‚ÄúIn every county I visited I heard stories of high grocery costs,‚Äù voiced Budd after a one hundred county tour. ‚ÄúSky rocketing fuel prices, shortages of basic necessities like infant formula, I even heard stories about families that had been ripped apart by fentanyl.‚ÄùAdditionally, he promised to hold President Joe Biden accountable for the multiple crises sweeping the country should he be elected to represent North Carolina in the senate this November.
image_caption: Ted Budd, Republican candidate for U.S. Senate, speaks during an election watch party on Tuesday, May 17, 2022, at WinMock at Kinderton in Bermuda Run, N.C. (Allison Lee Isley/The Winston-Salem Journal via AP)

story_headline: Congress holds first UFO hearing in half a century
story_copy: Congress holds first UFO hearing in half a centuryUnder Secretary of Defense for Intelligence and Security Ronald Moultrie, right, and Deputy Director of Naval Intelligence Scott Bray speak with a UAP on a screen, during a hearing of the House Intelligence, Counterterrorism, Counterintelligence, and Counterproliferation Subcommittee hearing on ‚ÄúUnidentified Aerial Phenomena,‚Äù on Capitol Hill, May 17, 2022, in Washington, D.C.OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:21 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, May 18, 2022Top secret information regarding extraterrestrial life was s officially delivered to the masses. The first hearing with top pentagon officials in half a century revealed the number of UAPs, or Unidentified Aerial Phenomena, reported by pilots and service members had grown to about 400 incidents. This is up from 143 from just a year ago.Undersecretary of Defense for Intelligence and Security, Ronald S. Moultrie said transparency was important. He also said the goal was to find out what‚Äôs out there, in addition to keeping US military and bases safe.‚ÄúWe know that our service members have encountered unidentified aerial phenomenon,‚Äù Moultrie stated. ‚ÄúAnd because UAPs pose potential flight safety and general security risks, we are committed to a focused effort to determine their origins.‚ÄùOther Pentagon officials stressed, the UAPs found do not appear to be of extraterrestrial origin. However, they recognized they have seen unauthorized and or unidentified aircraft since the early 2000s. Deputy Director of Naval Intelligence, Scott Bray proceeded to show a video example showing an observation in real time.‚ÄúAny given observation may be fleeting or longer,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúIt may be recorded or not. It may be observable by one or multiple assets. In short, there‚Äôs rarely an easy answer.‚ÄùFull resolution of metallic UAP/UFO cockpit video shown publicly in today‚Äôs congressional hearing. Makes you wonder what lawmakers saw in classified briefing that followed. pic.twitter.com/RfrWkJ5APs‚Äî Gadi Schwartz (@GadiNBC) May 17, 2022The Pentagon emphasized that it will be disclosing these types of videos and or evidence on a ‚Äúcase by case basis.‚Äù Officials stated that this is because if the UAP, indeed, represents a potential threat, these phenomena must be classified at appropriate levels.
image_caption: Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence and Security Ronald Moultrie, right, and Deputy Director of Naval Intelligence Scott Bray speak with a UAP on a screen, during a hearing of the House Intelligence, Counterterrorism, Counterintelligence, and Counterproliferation Subcommittee hearing on ‚ÄúUnidentified Aerial Phenomena,‚Äù on Capitol Hill, May 17, 2022, in Washington, D.C.
more_news: ¬†Biden Ignored Warnings, Signs Of Baby Formula ShortageTOPICS:CongressIntelligencenewsOANOANNPentagonpoliticsRonald MoultrieRonald S. MoultrieUFOUFOsunidentified aerial phenomena SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: GOP Reps. say Biden spending policies are creating massive inflation, crippling small businesses
story_copy: GOP Reps. say Biden spending policies are creating massive inflation, crippling small businessesFILE ‚Äì House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., speaks to reporters at his weekly news conference, at the Capitol in Washington, March 18, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:16 PM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, May 17, 2022GOP lawmakers lament President Joe Biden is letting the economy spiral out of control at the expense of small business owners.On Monday, House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) held a round table conference with representatives and business owners to discuss what‚Äôs going wrong with Biden‚Äôs approach to the economy.He stressed the President‚Äôs massive spending proposals and mismanagement of the federal government has led to the highest inflation rate since the 1980s. McCarthy added, as a former small business owner, he couldn‚Äôt imagine trying to operate during and after a pandemic.‚ÄúYou just came out of a pandemic hoping it would be better,‚Äù the congressman stated. ‚ÄúAnd then you‚Äôve got high regulations, higher gas prices, and in a small business you really learn the economic responsibility but you can‚Äôt just keep spending money. That‚Äôs what the government has been doing, propelling inflation along the way.‚ÄùCongresswoman Maria Salazar (R-Fla.) went on to say inflation is ‚Äúkilling the American dream.‚Äù She noted one-in-five small businesses in the country are created by minorities and around 70 percent of Miami businesses are minority owned. She claims the rising cost of raw materials and restrictive laws are making running those businesses more difficult.‚ÄúAll this is doing is killing the American dream,‚Äù said Salazar. ‚ÄúBecause the American dream for an immigrant is to create your small business.‚ÄùAdditionally, the business owners detailed the cost of soaring gas and food prices, which have caused them to raise the price of their goods..@RepFeenstra: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of fear right now in the breadbasket to the world‚Äù because of President Biden‚Äôs failed policies. pic.twitter.com/8Rp3H0KGvF‚Äî Kevin McCarthy (@GOPLeader) May 16, 2022Though these changes are driving customers away, they believe Americans are waking up to extreme leftist policies and will come out to vote for Republicans in the midterms.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., speaks to reporters at his weekly news conference, at the Capitol in Washington, March 18, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)

story_headline: Dallas P.D. announce arrest of suspect in Koreatown
story_copy: Dallas P.D. announce arrest of suspect in KoreatownCHICAGO, IL ‚Äì MAY 27: Crime scene tape is stretched around the front of a home where a man was shot on May 28, 2017 in Chicago, Illinois.(Photo by Scott Olson/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:49 PM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, May 17, 2022Dallas Police arrested a suspect in connection to a shooting at a Koreatown hair salon last Thursday. Jeremy Smith, 36, was taken into custody and charged with three counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon.Smith entered the Korean owned Hair World salon and began to shoot before fleeing the scene. Three women inside the salon were shot and hospitalized with non life-threatening injuries.‚Äù He entered the business and then began shooting multiple rounds,‚Äù said Dallas Police Department Sgt. Warren Mitchell. ‚ÄúVictims were transported to an area hospital.‚ÄùLocal and federal authorities say the event could be connected to two other shootings at Asian-owned businesses. Dallas Police Chief Eddie Garcia said that Smith had been involved in a car crash with an Asian man several years ago and has since suffered ‚Äúpanic attacks and delusions when he is around anyone of Asian descent.‚ÄùOn May 17, 2022, Dallas Police arrested Jeremy Smith, 36, and charged him with three counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon.¬† The charges stem from the May 11 shooting that injured three people at a hair salon located at 2216 Royal Lane.‚Äî Dallas Police Dept (@DallasPD) May 17, 2022‚ÄúLike I‚Äôve said previously, hate has no place in our city,‚Äù expressed Garcia. ‚ÄúThe men and women of the Dallas Police Department deeply care about the people we serve.‚ÄùThe FBI has officially opened a federal hate crime investigation.
image_caption: CHICAGO, IL ‚Äì MAY 27: Crime scene tape is stretched around the front of a home where a man was shot on May 28, 2017 in Chicago, Illinois.(Photo by Scott Olson/Getty Images)

story_headline: Project Veritas exposes Twitter, engineer says platform ‚Äòdoes not believe in free speech‚Äô
story_copy: Project Veritas exposes Twitter, engineer says platform ‚Äòdoes not believe in free speech‚ÄôFILE ‚Äì The Twitter application is seen on a digital device, Monday, April 25, 2022, in San Diego. (AP Photo/Gregory Bull)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 10:54 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, May 17, 2022A senior engineer at Twitter left no room for interpretation when asked about the social media companies definition of free speech.In an undercover Project Veritas investigation released on Monday, Siru Murugesan reacted to Elon Musk‚Äôs intended Twitter take over. He revealed his colleagues hate the idea of Musk purchasing Twitter.‚ÄúTwitter does not believe in free speech,‚Äù said Murugesan. ‚ÄúElon believes in free speech.‚ÄùThe Twitter engineer voiced how his coworkers did everything they could to disrupt Musk‚Äôs purchase. He described Twitter‚Äôs workplace culture as ‚Äúsocialist‚Äù after seeing coworkers get away with taking a month off of work at a time.‚ÄúIn Twitter, it‚Äôs like mental health is everything,‚Äù Murugesan stated. ‚ÄúIf you are not feeling it you can take some time off, people have taken months off.‚ÄùMurugesan claimed both liberals and conservatives cannot co-exist on Twitter, but ultimately admitted that Musk makes good points at times. The Tesla CEO has stated that work ethic expectations at Twitter will be extreme, but not less than what he demands of himself.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì The Twitter application is seen on a digital device, Monday, April 25, 2022, in San Diego. (AP Photo/Gregory Bull)
more_news: ¬†GOP Governors Ready For Roe To Be Overturned¬†TOPICS:Elon Muskfree speechnewsOANOANNpoliticssenior engineerSocial MediaTwitter SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_copy: Senate advances $40B Ukraine aid packageU.S. Republican Sens. Mitch McConnell, center, and from left, Susan Collins, John Cornyn and John Barrasso prepare to meet with Swedish media at the Grand Hotel in Stockholm after a meeting with Swedish Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson and Minister of Defense Peter Hultqvist on Sunday, May 15, 2022. McConnell said Sunday that Finland and Sweden would be ‚Äúimportant additions‚Äù to NATO as he led a delegation of GOP senators to the region in a show of support against Russia‚Äôs aggression. (Anders Wiklund/TT News Agency via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:14 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, May 17, 2022The Senate has advanced the $40 billion aid package for Ukraine. In an 81-to-11 vote Monday, the upper chamber overwhelmingly moved to put the measure to a final vote. The 11 senators who voted ‚Äòno,‚Äô including Tennessee Republican Bill Hagerty, expressed concerns of putting the war in Ukraine above American interests.The measure easily passed in the House, but was single handedly stalled in the upper chamber by Kentucky Sen, Rand Paul last week. The Republican said lawmakers must install a special inspector general to oversee how the Ukraine military aid is spent. Paul explained that his oath of office ‚Äúis to the national security of the United States of America.‚Äù‚ÄúThe US is trying to recover from the $1.6 trillion we spent on wars in the Middle East,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúNot to mention the $5 trillion borrowed for COVID. We should not forget that the Soviet Union collapsed in large part, not because it was defeated militarily, but because it ran out of money.‚ÄùThe lower chamber had passed the legislation in a 368-to-57 vote last week, just hours after the bill‚Äôs official text was released. All 57 opponents of the spending spree were Republicans. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) praised the bill‚Äôs passing as a monumental for a crisis that has raged for the past three months.‚ÄúWe should all be very proud that we had the opportunity when (Vladimir) Putin decided whatever it is he decided, to be brutal and cruel and a coward, that we were there to help,‚Äù stated the top Democrat. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about democracy versus a dictatorship.‚ÄùThe aid is supposedly split evenly between military and humanitarian efforts with billions of dollars going towards training Ukrainian troops, replenishing weapons stores, propping up the Ukrainian economy and aiding refugees in the US.The bill is $7 billion more than President Joe Biden‚Äôs initial request and will put the American aid to Ukraine up to $54 billion since the war first began. With its passing, Rep. Rosa DeLauro (D-Conn.) claimed the latest push will bring the crisis closer to a conclusion.‚ÄúThis bill ensures that we are one step closer to making them pay the full price for their actions,‚Äù she stated. ‚ÄúAnd in the process, we will be standing firmly with the Ukrainian people while combating the exploitation of Ukraine‚Äôs vulnerable financial system.‚ÄùBiden and the Democrat Party initially wanted to tie the package in with additional funding to combat COVID. However, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-K.Y.) had pledged to stand in the way of the bill‚Äôs passage unless COVID relief funds were dropped.I got to meet with Ukrainian Ambassador Markarova to discuss Ukraine's brave fight. Our brave friends are nowhere near out of the woods yet. Continued U.S. assistance must move at the speed of relevance to help Ukraine defeat the invaders and win this war. pic.twitter.com/TMgwNh4pyu‚Äî Leader McConnell (@LeaderMcConnell) May 10, 2022A final vote on the aid package is expected later this week.
image_caption: U.S. Republican Sens. Mitch McConnell, center, and from left, Susan Collins, John Cornyn and John Barrasso prepare to meet with Swedish media at the Grand Hotel in Stockholm after a meeting with Swedish Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson and Minister of Defense Peter Hultqvist on Sunday, May 15, 2022. McConnell said Sunday that Finland and Sweden would be ‚Äúimportant additions‚Äù to NATO as he led a delegation of GOP senators to the region in a show of support against Russia‚Äôs aggression. (Anders Wiklund/TT News Agency via AP)

story_headline: Karine Jean-Pierre hosts First briefing as press secy.
story_copy: Karine Jean-Pierre hosts First briefing as press secy.White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre takes a question from a reporter during her first press briefing as press secretary at the White House in Washington, Monday, May 16, 2022. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:51 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, May 17, 2022New White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre conducted her first press conference in the role. On Monday, she declared the press to be essential to a functioning democracy and said it‚Äôs okay to not see eye-to-eye on everything.Jean-Pierre also said she wants to be as transparent about the Biden administration as possible. She then pointed out her status as the first black and openly gay press secretary as historic.‚ÄúI am obviously acutely aware that my presence at this podium represents a few firsts,‚Äù said the Press Secretary. ‚ÄúI am a black, gay immigrant woman; the first of all three of those to hold this position. I would not be here today if it were not for generations of barriers, barrier breaking people before me. I stand on their shoulders.‚Äù.@PressSec Karine Jean-Pierre: "I am a Black, gay, immigrant woman. The first of all three of those to hold this position. I would not be here today if it were not for generations of barrier-breaking people before me. I stand on their shoulders." pic.twitter.com/KZj3Z4GkEL‚Äî CSPAN (@cspan) May 16, 2022Jean-Pierre has a history of controversial comments such as declaring 45th President Donald Trump to be illegitimately elected and claiming that racism ‚Äúinvades every part of US society.‚Äù
image_caption: White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre takes a question from a reporter during her first press briefing as press secretary at the White House in Washington, Monday, May 16, 2022. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)

story_headline: 15 public safety officers receive Medal of Valor
story_copy: 15 public safety officers receive Medal of ValorPresident Joe Biden awards Stamford, Ct., Fire Fighter Chad Titus the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor in the East Room of the White House, Monday, May 16, 2022, in Washington. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:45 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, May 17, 2022The White House hosted a ceremony on Monday to honor public safety officers who performed acts of heroism.President Joe Biden and Attorney General Merrick Garland recognized 15 public safety officers by awarding them with a Medal of Valor. Biden gave the award to the 2020 and 2021 classes after the COVID-19 pandemic postponed both ceremonies.The Medal of Valor is the highest honor a public safety officer can receive for performing acts of heroism.‚ÄúToday is an important day for the nation to give thanks for all that you do for everybody, for all of us,‚Äù Biden said. ‚ÄúBecause of COVID-19 we couldn‚Äôt have this special ceremony for the past two years, but I‚Äôm honored that we finally can today. Fifteen public safety officers from eight different departments with a Medal of Valor, the highest award a president can bestow on a public safety officer.‚ÄùThe recipients of the award included nine police officers and six fire fighters. One recipient was a North Carolina police officer who tragically passed away after saving a woman during a hostage situation in a busy retail area.‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the heart and soul and the very spine, very spine of this country and your communities,‚Äù he proclaimed. ‚ÄúEach one of you from small town departments to big cities, you‚Äôre cut from the same cloth. You possess a selflessness that‚Äôs really hard to explain. A rare commitment to your neighbors and your fellow Americans, an unusual bravery that inspires everyone and you‚Äôve been singled out because of your extraordinary heroism.‚ÄùToday, I awarded the Medal of Valor to 15 public safety officers ‚Äì including two who died in the line of duty. These heroes represent the best of who we are as Americans ‚Äì and these medals reflect the profound gratitude of our nation. pic.twitter.com/4DS4VNb7tL‚Äî President Biden (@POTUS) May 17, 2022Biden ended the ceremony by paying tribute to a retired Buffalo police officer who was killed during a mass shooting incident, which left 10 people dead and three others injured. The President is set to visit Buffalo on Tuesday in light of the tragic incident.
image_caption: President Joe Biden awards Stamford, Ct., Fire Fighter Chad Titus the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor in the East Room of the White House, Monday, May 16, 2022, in Washington. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)

story_headline: Fla. Governor Desantis to invest $100 million for cancer research in the state
story_copy: Fla. Governor Desantis to invest $100 million for cancer research in the stateFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis speaks to supporters before signing a 15-week abortion ban into law Thursday, April 14, 2022, in Kissimmee, Fla. (AP Photo/John Raoux)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:51 AM PT ‚Äì Thursday, May 19, 2022Florida Governor Ron Desantis (R-Fla.) will be investing $100 million for cancer research in the state. He announced the initiative during a press conference on Tuesday. Desantis‚Äô wife First Lady Casey Desantis is a recent breast cancer survivor and said that the state would lead the way to find a cure for all types of cancer.‚ÄúWe believe that cancer initiatives is very significant in the state of Florida,‚Äù the governor stated. It‚Äôs consistently been the second leading cause of death just behind heart disease, I think that‚Äôs pretty typical for what you see around the country. Over the last year this is something that has taken a large impact on our family.‚ÄùHonored and humbled to join @GovRonDeSantis to announce a historic $100 million investment for Florida‚Äôs nationally recognized cancer centers to advance life-saving research and care. pic.twitter.com/Ga92TzrA6A‚Äî Casey DeSantis (@FLCaseyDeSantis) May 17, 2022Desantis added that many people in Florida have been affected in some way or another by cancer. Desantis declared that since his wife‚Äôs diagnosis he began to do research and look at what people have been able to do, that information gave him a new sense of hope.‚ÄúHe stood by me the entire time, he never missed a chemo appointment,‚Äù the First Lady voiced. ‚ÄúSix of those sitting in there very uncomfortable and he held my hand through everything. This is a game changer, Florida is going to lead the way to find a definitive cure once and for all and it‚Äôs gonna happen here because of this leadership.‚ÄùThe funding will go towards cancer centers in Florida which will increase their research funding by 60-percent.
image_caption: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis speaks to supporters before signing a 15-week abortion ban into law Thursday, April 14, 2022, in Kissimmee, Fla. (AP Photo/John Raoux)

story_headline: Fla. man tased by sheriff while pumping gas
story_copy: Fla. man tased by sheriff while pumping gasMotorcycle enthusiasts attend the 81st annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally on August 8, 2021 in Sturgis, South Dakota. (Photo by Scott Olson/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:00 PM PT ‚Äì Thursday, May 19, 2022Jean Baretto continues to fight for his life after sheriff‚Äôs tasered him at a gas pump nearly three months ago. On Wednesday, it was revealed that Baretto‚Äôs legal team has allegedly obtained surveillance footage from a WaWa gas station in Central Florida where the incident took place. The incident shows their client being tackled from behind by one deputy while another hits him with a taser.That taser shot ignited the fire ball that engulfed Barreto and two nearby deputy‚Äôs according to the State Fire Marshall. The family and attorney‚Äôs of the man say he never committed a crime.At the time of the incident Osceola Sheriff‚Äôs Department alleged that Barretto was part of motorcyclists that were harassing and pointing guns at other drivers. His lawyers claim the video shows the 26-year old was not trying to flee and question why an electrical charge would be deployed at someone dealing with a highly flammable liquid.‚ÄúIn Osceola County we have no tolerance for this type of behavior,‚Äù said Osceola Sheriff Marcos Lopez. ‚ÄúWe will identify you and catch you, even if you flee into another county.‚ÄùThe Attorney‚Äôs have asked for a renewed investigation as the sheriff‚Äôs office has not released any additional information including body camera video. On Tuesday, he underwent his sixth surgery since the fire. Doctors say he still has a long road to recovery. His lawyers state that he has been fighting for his life for the past 80 days with third-degree burns over 75-percent of his body.‚ÄúWe‚Äôre calling today for FDLE to take this case over or to have the U.S. Justice Department take this case over,‚Äù declared the NeJame Law Group. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs too much going on, too many questions that need to be asked.‚ÄùJean Baretto still has not been arrested or charged with any crime.
image_caption: Motorcycle enthusiasts attend the 81st annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally on August 8, 2021 in Sturgis, South Dakota. (Photo by Scott Olson/Getty Images)

story_headline: Ariz. Border Patrol agents report increased migrant activity
story_copy: Ariz. Border Patrol agents report increased migrant activityHomeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas listens to Raul Ortiz, Chief, U.S. Border Patrol, as he tours the section of the border wall with Mexico, Tuesday, May 17, 2022, in La Joya, Texas. (Joel Martinez/The Monitor via AP, Pool)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:50 AM PT ‚Äì Thursday, May 19, 2022Border Patrol agents in Arizona are preparing for the expiration of Title 42. Agents say they are experiencing a surge in migrant encounters near their checkpoint in Tucson. On Wednesday, they voiced that their encounters are vastly different from those reported in other border states such as Texas and California.Additionally, they‚Äôve seen a 25-percent increase in 911 calls about illegal border crossings with authorities receiving up to 16 calls per day. Title 42 was put in place during the Trump administration and allowed border agents to turn away migrants attempting to cross into the country due to the COVID-19 pandemic.‚ÄúOur numbers of apprehensions or encounters is more than 130,000 fiscal year to date,‚Äù said Border Agent Jesus Vasabilaso. ‚ÄúSo our fiscal year started in October and then all the way to today. That‚Äôs up more than 50-percent compared to last year.‚ÄùTo combat this surge officials set up a working partnership with the Mexican National Guard to apprehend illegal migrants attempting to cross from both sides of the border.‚ÄúWe do what we call mirror patrol,‚Äù stated¬† Vasabilaso. We‚Äôll patrol on our side, they‚Äôll patrol on their side, so we‚Äôre both looking for any bad actors around the border. They‚Äôre looking for any ladders that smugglers will utilize to get people up and over the fence, they‚Äôre looking for people that are up to no good trying to assault migrants. If Title-42 goes away the border is not going to be open.‚ÄùTitle 42 is set to expire on May 23, but a federal judge in Louisiana is expected to hand down a ruling which could keep Title 42 in place.
image_caption: Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas listens to Raul Ortiz, Chief, U.S. Border Patrol, as he tours the section of the border wall with Mexico, Tuesday, May 17, 2022, in La Joya, Texas. (Joel Martinez/The Monitor via AP, Pool)

story_headline: At least 6 injured in fire at Wis. construction facility
story_copy: At least 6 injured in fire at Wis. construction facilityThis May 5, 2022 photo provided by the in the Sparta Area Fire District in Wisconsin shows a house fire that killed four people in Little Falls, Wis. Authorities say four people have died in a house fire in small town in east central Wisconsin. (Sparta Area Fire District via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 12:35 PM PT ‚Äì Thursday, May 19, 2022A massive fire at a construction facility in Wisconsin left at least six people injured. Reports say the blaze started Thursday morning following a series of explosions at Summerset Marine Construction in Waukesha County, southwest of Milwaukee.‚ÄúAbout 100 firefighters responded to the scene after the explosion,‚Äù said Western Fire District Assistant Chief Matt Haerter. ‚ÄúThe fire was reported to dispatchers about 7:30 a.m.‚Äù.RIGHT NOW:  An explosion at a #Wisconsin marine construction company causes a huge fire, sending a massive cloud of black smoke billowing from the building. It's not yet clear how it started or whether there were any injuries.#Eagle #WisconsinFire pic.twitter.com/qm7I1pk7Wp‚Äî Shaquille Omari (@shaq_omari) May 19, 2022The injured included three civilians and three firefighters. One civilian and a fire fighter were hospitalized, while the other victims were treated at the scene.According to Haerter, part of the building collapsed which made it difficult for firefighters to get to the source of the blaze. 24 people were in the building when the fire broke out and all including the injured were outside by the time firefighters arrived.Schools and business in the area were evacuated and residents near the facility were told to ‚Äúshelter in place‚Äù.
image_caption: This May 5, 2022 photo provided by the in the Sparta Area Fire District in Wisconsin shows a house fire that killed four people in Little Falls, Wis. Authorities say four people have died in a house fire in small town in east central Wisconsin. (Sparta Area Fire District via AP)

story_headline: Fed Chair Jerome Powell: We will fight to lower inflation, unemployment
story_copy: Fed Chair Jerome Powell: We will fight to lower inflation, unemploymentFederal Reserve Board chairman Jerome Powell on Capitol Hill in Washington. (Graeme Jennings/Pool via AP, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 3: 20 PM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, May 18, 2022Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell (R-D.C.) doubled down on the policy of raising interest rates in coming months which may hurt millions of Americans. In an interview Tuesday, the fed chair admitted higher borrowing costs may cause some ‚Äúpain‚Äù to households and businesses.However, he said it is necessary to curb runaway inflation and their is no way around it. Powell added that he originally hoped the federal reserve could stifle inflation without affecting the labor market but warns unemployment may rise slightly.‚ÄúI would love to see a labor market that is more in balance, ideally that would start with the number of vacancies coming down,‚Äù said Powell. ‚ÄúVacancies and quits are at an all time high, that suggests the labor market that‚Äôs out of balance. Their are more demands than their are workers. I‚Äôd love to see people come back into the labor force, We are seeing some of that now, we‚Äôd like to see that continue and we‚Äôd love to see the job vacancies come back so that your seeing supply and demand get back together‚ÄùHe went on to urge Americans not to worry about the labor market claiming the unemployment rate is now near a 50-year low. He further touted the structure of the U.S. economy saying he believes America will come out of the post-pandemic era strong despite the issues driving inflation. He vows to keep fighting inflation until it slows back down to two percent.‚ÄúIf that involves moving passed their wont be any hesitation about that,‚Äù he stated.Many economists criticized the fed chair for waiting too long before raising rates this year, but he believes his policies were ‚Äúappropriate‚Äù. Some economists says riding fed rates may cause a recession in coming months.Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve Chairman predicts several shifts in the U.S economy that could slow down the rate of globalization.
image_caption: Federal Reserve Board chairman Jerome Powell on Capitol Hill in Washington. (Graeme Jennings/Pool via AP, File)

story_headline: Sen. McConnell blames bad economy on Democrat policies
story_copy: Sen. McConnell blames bad economy on Democrat policiesSenate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., speaks with reporters following a closed-door policy lunch, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, May 17, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:15 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, May 18, 2022Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) berated his Democrat colleagues for reckless spending while forcing the American people to foot the bill. While addressing the Senate floor Tuesday, the Kentuckian evoked the memory of economic prosperity under Republican leadership.‚ÄúIn early 2020, before the pandemic, Republicans helped create one of the best economic moments for working Americans literally in out lifetimes,‚Äù McConnell stated. ‚ÄúUnemployment was low, inflation was low and real take-home pat was rising steadily. In fact, we had wages rising faster for the bottom 25 percent of the wage scale than for the top 25 percent.‚ÄùThe Minority leader noted, the COVID pandemic caused an artificial speed bump for the American economy. He claimed the incoming Democrat government had been set up for success in January of last year as much of the private sector was reopening and COVID vaccines were readily available. However, the long serving senator lamented the political left snatched defeat from the jaws of victory and squandered the good position they had inherited.‚ÄúBut through their far-left policy choices, Washington Democrats have driven our economy right into the ground,‚Äù he asserted. ‚ÄúInflation is setting 40-year records in consecutive months, gas and diesel prices have set new all-time highs on consecutive days, and sticker shock continues to cause headaches for Americans buying household essentials.‚ÄùGas prices are now the highest they have ever been in American history. Americans are now paying roughly $4.40 per gallon. That‚Äôs up about two whole dollars from when President Biden put his hand on the Bible.‚Äî Leader McConnell (@LeaderMcConnell) May 11, 2022McConnell recounted tales from around the country of people scrounging to support themselves amid steep price hikes. From taking out loans to afford food to visiting multiple stores for the lowest prices, the Republican highlighted the various ways Americans have grappled with the 10 percent rise in grocery costs in the past year. However, he accused Democrats of treating government spending as the only solution, which he said is exacerbating the problem.‚ÄúFewer than one-in-four American consumers say that this current economic conditions are even ‚Äòsomewhat good‚Äô and fewer than one-in-five say the Biden administration‚Äôs policies haven‚Äôt done anything to help,‚Äù McConnell continued. ‚ÄúDemocrats made runaway reckless spending their new normal here in Washington. So historic, painful inflation has become the new normal for working families everywhere else.‚ÄùDespite chastising Democrats for excessive spending, the Minority Leader has been instrumental in drumming up Republican support to advance the $40 billion Ukraine bill in the Senate.
image_caption: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., speaks with reporters following a closed-door policy lunch, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, May 17, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)

story_headline: Trump-backed Doug Mastriano wins Pa. GOP primary
story_copy: Trump-backed Doug Mastriano wins Pa. GOP primaryState Sen. Doug Mastriano, R-Franklin, a Republican candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania, takes part in a primary night election gathering in Chambersburg, Pa., Tuesday, May 17, 2022. (AP Photo/Carolyn Kaster)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:00 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, May 18, 2022Trump-endorsed candidate Doug Mastriano (R-Pa.) won the Pennsylvania GOP primary for governor. The Associated Press declared Mastriano the winner on Tuesday with more than 42-percent of the vote and 65-percent precincts reporting. Lou Barletta (R-Pa.) trailed behind him at 23-percent and Bill McSwain (R-Pa.) received 15-percent.‚ÄúThere is no one in Pennsylvania who has done more, or fought harder, for Election Integrity than State Senator Doug Mastriano,‚Äù the former President Donald Trump said in a statement.¬†Thank you üôèüèª For Voting For Doug4Gov!!! This is YOUR win, Pennsylvania!  To God Be The Glory!! pic.twitter.com/CzEE4ESi6y‚Äî Doug Mastriano (@dougmastriano) May 18, 2022During an election rally the new GOP primary governor said his campaign has no place for ‚Äúhate, bigotry and tolerance.‚Äù He added, his movement is under siege from members of the mainstream media.Shortly after the polls on Tuesday, two-term Attorney General Josh Shapiro (D-Pa.) expressed on Twitter how ‚Äúhumbled and honored‚Äù he is to be the Democratic nominee for Pennsylvania governor.‚ÄúNo matter which dangerous extremist we‚Äôre against this November, the stakes are too damn high for anything but a victory,‚Äù voiced Shapiro.The two will face off in the general election on Nov. 8.
